texts.en: Sa Em, 50, lives in Dambae district of Kampong Cham province. She is a mother of five children, two of whom are dependent on her and still in school. To support her family, she grows cassava on a hectare of farmland as the main source of her income. Moreover, she grows rice and raises pigs to supplement her income. This is her ninth time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and she fully repaid her past loans. She leads the group of two to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland, as well as pig feed. She hopes that she can improve her farmland to get more yield. She will use the profits to fulfill her dream of renovating her old house.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland, as well as pig feed

loans.name: Melanya

texts.en:
This nice lady made a decision to have one more deal with Kiva simultaneously with her first one. She is paying back her loan on time and according to her graphic. She bought a computer which is now an integral part of her work. She still works at the Linguistic Center as an English Language teacher. Melanya says that she feels happy with the choice of her work which coincides with her profession and she enjoys working with students. Being so young, Melanya, thanks to her intelligence, is greatly respected in the institution where she works.

Melanya lives in Yerevan city with her parents and brother. She at this time has a good chance of taking part in training courses of pedagogical methodology. These are paid courses and she will use this Kiva loan to pay for them.

loans.use: to pay for training courses of pedagogical methodology

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a 26-year-old  married woman with 3 children. She sells clothes and it has been profitable. 

She will use the loan to purchase clothes and earn more income to enable her to support her family.  She will educate her children and buy food for the family.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to improve her business and earn enough income to educate her children to the university level.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for sell.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette is aged 59 years old. She is married with six children aged between 9 and 28 years old. They all go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 30 years, while her husband is a farmer also. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children and to improve her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Japhet

texts.en:
Japhet is 29 years old. He is married with two children aged one and three years old who are not yet going to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 12 years. Also his wife is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land and to improve his welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence is 85  years old. She is a widower, a farmer, and has grown maize for the past 50 years. She would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Manana

texts.en:
Manana is a 39-years-old widowed woman who lives in the small village of Baghdati district with her 2 children. The only source of income for the family is from a family-owned vineyard. Manana produces wine to sell locally for income. The income is only seasonal and not enough for the family. 

Manana has a great desire to increase her family's income and start a business. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan  of 450 USD  to purchase  clothes to sell to neighbors and villagers. Manana will be able to  provide better living conditions for her children.

loans.use: to begin a business to sell clothes.

loans.name: M. Nadeem

texts.en:
M. Nadeem Ali is a 29-year-old young and energetic person living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. He is the father of a son and lives near his clothing shop. This clothing shop is the only source of income for his family. He devotes all his efforts and time to the garment shop. 

His shop is situated by the clothing market and there are a lot of competitors in the market. Due to this competition, it is very difficult to convince customers to pay a high price. This competition becomes the cause of low sales and increased effort. He has to maintain the latest designs, rates and delightful colors of clothing for his shop so that he can maintain the rate of sales.

The summer season is about to start and he does not have sufficient cash to buy summer clothing. If he cannot replace the summers season's clothing with winter season's clothing, it might highly affect his sales. He does not want to reduce his sales and his monthly income. 

M. Nadeem Ali has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan so that he can  to buy summer clothing.

M. Nadeem Ali hopes that he will purchase clothing at the right time to cope with the market competition and increase his income as well. He thanks Kiva and its field partner for this support.

loans.use: to purchase summer season clothing.

loans.name: Rum's Group

texts.en:
Rum is a 48-year-old mother of four children  living in Koh Sotin district of Kampong Cham province,. 

She and her family struggle for a living growing rice and sesame as the main sources of income.  She works as a tailor to supplement income. 

This is her second time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and she successfully repaid her previous loan. She leads a 3-member group  to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy a sewing machine to support her business. 

She hopes that she can expand her current business and increase her earnings.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

location.town: Kampong Cham Province, Koh Sotin District

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
Marisa engages in farming. She grows and sells rice. In addition to that, she also raises and sells hogs. She is a 55-year-old married woman with six children. Two of her children are still attending school.

She is asking for a loan to buy farming supplies like fertilizer and pay for the laborers. This will improve her farming business and augment the yield of her farm. With this, she could manage her income properly and start to expand her business. Marisa hopes to be able to continue to send her children to school for a brighter future.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies like fertilizer and pay for the laborers.
